Frío intenso y extremas nevadas no dan tregua en EEUU: Nueva York y Ohio son algunos estados afectados
De acuerdo con las autoridades, Ohio, Michigan, Pensilvania y Nueva York son los estados más afectados del país y se reportan caídas de tendidos eléctricos junto con carreteras cubiertas en hielo.
No dejes de ver:
En realidad aumentada te explicamos de dónde viene el aire frío que azota a varias zonas de EEUU.

Univision
,

author: @thecryptobasic
title: Why Ethereum’s Smart Contracts Are One of Its Best Features
text: Blockchain has emerged as a game-changing technology, disrupting numerous industries by providing a decentralized and safe solution for making transactions. One of the most common uses of blockchain is implementing smart contracts. But what are they, and how do they work? First of all, smart contracts have everything to do with Ethereum, the 2nd leading digital asset in the crypto market which you can buy on the [Binance](https://www.binance.com/en/price/ethereum) platform. Ethereum was also the one to bring the concept of automation to life and shape the future of blockchain technology. To be fair, trying to make sense of blockchain and all its related aspects can feel like an attempt to solve a Rubik’s cube in a room with no light – it’s truly daunting. If this concept is too complicated for you, we’re here to shine a light on smart contracts to help you grasp everything from how it functions to its benefits and the industries making the most of this new and appealing tech advancement. Breaking Down the Concept of Smart Contracts If you are familiar with the blockchain space, you may have heard about smart contracts before. But what are they, really? If you’re associating them with paper contracts – but smarter- you’re not wrong. Simply put, Ethereum smart contracts run on the Ethereum blockchain and are self-executing. This means that the terms of the agreement are written into code, executing automatically once specific conditions have been met. Smart contracts not only eliminate the need for an intermediary, but they also leave no room for misinterpretation. Since smart contracts automate contract execution, they save time and reduce the risk of human mistakes, making them ideal for different industries, including supply chain management, banking, and real estate. Some examples of Ethereum smart contracts include: - Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs). As the name suggests, these are companies run by smart contracts, operating based on rules written into the contract. - Decentralized Exchanges (DEXes). They are platforms that allow you to trade digital assets without requiring an intermediary.The smart contract is like a trusty referee that ensures everyone plays fair. - Initial Coin Offerings (ICOs). You can think of ICOs as fundraisers – except that you don’t sell car washes or cookies but cryptocurrencies. The smart contract’s role is to manage the sale to ensure all parties get their fair share. The Incredible Advantages of Ethereum Smart Contracts Ethereum smart contracts provide numerous benefits to individuals and businesses alike. They decrease transaction costs while boosting efficiency, as an intermediary is no longer needed. The smart contract does the entire job, acting like an efficient personal assistant who doesn’t make any errors. Due to their self-executing nature, smart contracts ensure that the agreement terms are enforced automatically, boosting transaction transparency and security. One of smart contracts’ highlights is the element of trust. Since they ensure prompt execution of transactions based on specified conditions, the possibilities for error, manipulation or human bias are significantly lower. More than 70% of executives see smart contracts as an innovative tool that will shape the future of business. Moreover, the market for DeFi apps built on the Ethereum blockchain has risen exponentially in only a few years, showing the potential of smart contracts to revolutionize how companies operate. Sectors That Are Making the Most of Ethereum Smart Contracts Ethereum smart contracts are used in different industries, including supply chain, real estate, gaming, FinTech, banking, etc. Smart contracts offer efficient solutions to these businesses, allowing them to operate as efficiently as possible. For instance, smart contracts streamline payroll processing in the HR sector, resulting in accurate and timely salary disbursement according to predefined conditions, including company policies and work hours. The technology of smart contracts can also benefit the recruitment process by encoding the terms of employment offers, thus resulting in transparent and seamless job acceptance processes. Healthcare is another sector where smart contracts are making their mark. By streamlining patient data management, smart contracts allow authorized healthcare providers to access essential information safely and promptly. Healthcare gains enormously from including blockchain smart contracts, and one of the most notable benefits is the potential to revolutionize clinical trial conduct. This is achieved by recording trial data safely and ensuring the results’ integrity and transparency. The gaming industry is also going through a transformation due to smart contracts that enhance players’ experiences and enable more autonomy by providing ownership of in-game assets represented by NFTs (non-fungible tokens). Smart contracts technology encourages fair play through the enforcement of game rules and governance of randomized events in an auditable and transparent way. Moreover, they enable play-to-earn models, which are an innovative monetization tool. Through their programmable nature, smart contracts blend digital activities with visible economic perks, automating the distribution of real-life rewards related to in-game actions. Are There Any Limitations in Adopting Smart Contracts? As much as we’d like to say smart contracts are perfect, that’s far from true. Although understanding how Ethereum smart contracts work unlocks many benefits, discussing the limitations is also imperative. Smart contracts are just like a coin – they have two different sides, and one of them is not so bright. Firstly, immutability is one of smart contracts’ main characteristics, meaning that once you create a contract, it is impossible to change it in any way. It’s like writing words in wet cement – they remain there forever. Well, the same applies to smart contracts, potentially representing a problem if conditions change or an error is made. Another limitation of smart contracts is associated with the legal framework. There are still many locations around the world where smart contracts’ legality is still ambiguous. It’s like exploring an unknown territory without any ideas of what could happen along the way. Moreover, the issue of privacy is also major. Think of it as living in a house that has glass walls – although it may look great, everyone can see inside, invading your privacy. And no, we aren’t talking metaphorically – your privacy is actually compromised due to Ethereum smart contracts transparency. Although it is perceived as a good thing -which it is, as it enhances trust – transparency allows all network users to see what you’re doing, which is less than ideal. Looking Towards the Future As reports show, the global smart contract market will reach $1.4 billion two years from now, an increase of 25.2% from 2020. There’s no doubt that Ethereum smart contracts hold great potential in the future, so we can expect to see further adoption, expansion of DApps, emergence of new use cases, and so on. Overall, we can expect Ethereum smart contracts to experience further development in the years to come. Follow Us on [Facebook.](https://www.facebook.com/thecryptobasic/) Disclaimer: This content is informational and should not be considered financial advice. The views expressed in this article may include the author's personal opinions and do not reflect The Crypto Basic’s opinion. Readers are encouraged to do thorough research before making any investment decisions. The Crypto Basic is not responsible for any financial losses. -Advertisement-

author: @infobae
title: Temas del día de EFE España del sábado 2 de noviembre de 2024 - Infobae
text:
TEMPORAL INUNDACIONES
Valencia/Madrid - Con más de 200 muertos a causa de la dana, la mayoría en la provincia de Valencia, la solidaridad ciudadana se abre paso desde toda España para hacer llegar ayuda a los damnificados, atendidos por miles de voluntarios en las zonas más afectadas y en medio del dolor por las víctimas en el tercer día de luto oficial.
(Texto) (Foto) (Vídeo) (Audio)
PARTIDOS ERC (ANÁLISIS)
Barcelona - ERC celebrará el 30 de noviembre un convulso congreso con el que Oriol Junqueras quiere hacerse nuevamente con la presidencia del partido, después de que Carles Puigdemont haya vuelto a situarse al frente de Junts.
(Texto) (Foto)
PUENTE AÉREO
Madrid - El Puente Aéreo entre Madrid y Barcelona, inaugurado en 1974 como la primera ruta de este tipo en Europa, cumple 50 años, resistiéndose a la competencia del tren de alta velocidad que, desde que empezó a enlazar ambas ciudades en 2008, ha ido ganando cuota de mercado al avión, hasta llegar al 82 % actual.
(Texto) (Recursos de archivo en www.lafototeca.com cod 5338825, 661195 y otros)
VÍCTIMAS TERRORISMO
San Sebastián - El Colectivo de Víctimas del Terrorismo Covite entrega su XXIII Premio Internacional al escritor italiano Mario Calabresi y a la librería Lagun de San Sebastián, con el fin de reconocer el papel de la literatura como medio de transmisión de la memoria del terrorismo.
(Texto) (Foto) (Vídeo)
- El acto comienza a las 12:00 horas
JOAQUÍN ARAÚJO (ENTREVISTA)
Mérida - El escritor y periodista Joaquín Araújo, Premio Nacional de Medio Ambiente y Premio Global 500 de la ONU, considera en una entrevista con EFE que la "estupidez" lleva al ser humano a la contradicción de destruir lo que en el fondo prefiere y denuncia que este sistema económico devorador ha provocado que la naturaleza esté "muy enferma". Por Carlos González de Rivera.
(Texto) (Recursos de archivo en www.lafototeca.com cod 14711778 y otros)
SECTOR MICOLÓGICO
Madrid - El sector dedicado a la recolección y comercialización de setas y trufas busca más unidad en España y dar un impulso a su profesionalización en medio de un escenario con escasa legislación, mientras que el turismo asociado (micoturismo) está en pleno auge y vive estas semanas su temporada fuerte.
(Texto) (Recursos de archivo en www.lafototeca.com cod 7220507 y otros)
LITERATURA EE.UU.
Madrid - Tras una campaña electoral marcada por la polarización y la tensión extrema, el próximo martes se celebran las elecciones presidenciales en Estados Unidos que confrontan a Donald Trump y Kamala Harris. Estos son algunos ensayos recientes para seguir estos comicios y profundizar en las claves de la situación política actual. Por Magdalena Tsanis.
(Texto a las 10:00 horas. 980 palabras)
MÚSICA SALUD (ENTREVISTA)
Madrid - Rosana Corbacho, una de las pocas psicólogas que se han especializado en atención a artistas de la música, repasa en una entrevista con EFE su experiencia en implementar "giras saludables". Por Javier Herrero.
(Texto a las 10:30 horas. 801 palabras)
MÚSICA PIANO
Cádiz - A punto de cumplir 70 años, el mítico pianista de jazz estadounidense Fred Hersch asegura que la música "es la vida" que necesita, y define el jazz como "un estilo universal, que no tiene fronteras, y permite entenderse entre ellos a músicos que hablen distintos idiomas". Por Fermín Cabanillas.
(Texto) (Foto) (Vídeo) (Audio)
AGENDA
POLÍTICA
09:00h.- Madrid.- TEMPORAL INUNDACIONES.- El presidente del Gobierno, Pedro Sánchez, preside el Comité de crisis para el seguimiento de los efectos de la dana. Complejo de la Moncloa. Cobertura oficial. (Texto) (Foto) (Vídeo)
10:03h.- Álora (Málaga).- TEMPORAL INUNDACIONES.- El coordinador general de IU Andalucía y diputado de Sumar en el Congreso, Toni Valero; la coordinadora provincial de IU Málaga, Toni Morillas, y el diputado provincial de Con Málaga, Juan Márquez, atienden a los medios de comunicación en relación con los efectos provocados por la dana. En el Puente de Madera de el Barrio el Puente.
11:00h.- Letur (Albacete).- TEMPORAL INUNDACIONES.- El presidente del Partido Popular de Castilla-La Mancha, Paco Núñez, visita la localidad de Letur, afectada por la dana. Habrá atención a medios. Colegio Virgen de la Asunción.
12:00 h.- Torrejón de Ardoz (Madrid).- TEMPORAL INUNDACIONES.- El presidente del Gobierno, Pedro Sánchez, visita el Cuartel General de la UME y mantiene una reunión de trabajo con sus responsables. Asiste la ministra de Defensa. (Texto) (Foto) (Vídeo)
12:00h.- Santander.- MEMORIA HISTÓRICA.- La Plataforma de Memoria Histórica y Democrática convoca una manifestación en Santander contra la derogación de la Ley de Memoria Histórica autonómica de 2021, que debate este próximo lunes el pleno del Parlamento de Cantabria. Plaza de Numancia. (Texto) (Foto)
JUSTICIA Y SEGURIDAD
12:00h.- San Sebastián.- VÍCTIMAS TERRORISMO.- Acto de entrega de del XXIII Premio Internacional de Covite al escritor Mario Calabresi y a la librería Lagun. Palacio Miramar. (Texto) (Foto)
SOCIEDAD
10:00h.- Logroño.- TEMPORAL INUNDACIONES.- El presidente de la Federación Riojana de Municipios, Jorge Loyo, y el alcalde Logroño, Conrado Escobar, informan sobre el dispositivo para la recogida de donaciones de material y recursos para los municipios afectados por la dana. Puerta antigua estación de Autobuses. (Texto) (Foto)
11:00h.- San Sebastián.- ARANZADI HOMENAJE.- La estación biológica de Doñana y la primera mujer anilladora de aves de España son homenajeadas por la sociedad de ciencias Aranzadi en un acto en el Ayuntamiento de San Sebastián. Salón de plenos del Ayuntamiento.
16:00h.- Madrid.- RTVE OPOSICIONES.- Las pruebas de las oposiciones de RTVE para la categoría de Información y Contenidos. Facultad de Ciencias Económicas y Empresariales, Facultad de Psicología, y Facultad de Políticas y Sociología de la Universidad Complutense de Madrid, Campus de Somosaguas. (Texto) (Foto)
CULTURA
11:00h.- Palma.- FESTIVAL EVOLUTION.- Presentación de 'Las chicas de la estación', con la directora Juana Macías y las actrices Julieta Tobío, Salua Hadra y Maria Steelman, en el XIII Evolution Mallorca International Film Festival. Hotel Portixol, Carrer de la Sirena 27.
13:00h.- Palma.- FESTIVAL EVOLUTION.- Presentación de 'Amanece en Semaná', con el director Rafa Cortés y los protagonistas: Luis Tosar, Luisa Mayol, Luis Zahera y Bárbara Santa-Cruz, en el XIII Evolution Mallorca International Film Festival. Hotel Portixol, Carrer de la Sirena 27.
20:30h.- Madrid.- MUSEO PRADO.- El Museo del Prado abre en horario nocturno la exposición 'El Taller de Rubens', compuesta por más de 30 obras del artista. Museo del Prado.
20:30h.- Logroño.- BRUJAS ZUGARRAMURDI.- El 'Auto de fe de 1610', en el que fueron ajusticiadas las conocidas como 'brujas de Zugarramurdi', se representa en Logroño. Paseo de El Espolón. (Texto) (Foto) (Vídeo) (Audio)
21:00h.- Las Palmas de Gran Canaria.- MÚSICA MECANO.- Espectáculo de homenaje a Mecano, 'Hija de la Luna', protagonizado por la cantante Robin Torres, en el papel de Ana Torroja. Auditorio Alfredo Kraus.
21:30h.- Santa Cruz de Tenerife.- MÚSICA ROCK.- Concierto de Robe Iniesta en Santa Cruz de Tenerife. Palmetum.

author: Ed Wittenberg | eswittenberg@yahoo.com
title: Orange High School senior Olivia Ullner earns prestigious Girl Scout Gold Award
text:
Orange resident Olivia Ullner, a senior at Orange High School, displays she proclamation she received from Mayor Judson Kline at the Village Council meeting Wednesday (Dec. 4) in recognition of having earned the prestigious Girl Scout Gold Award. (Ed Wittenberg, special to cleveland.com)
By Ed Wittenberg, special to cleveland.com ORANGE, Ohio -- Olivia Ullner, a senior at Orange High School and an Orange resident, has earned the prestigious Girl Scout Gold Award.
On Wednesday (Dec. 4), Village Council recognized Olivia’s achievement, with Mayor Judson Kline presenting her with a proclamation from his office.
“This is an important step in leadership development for young people,” Kline said after reading the proclamation.
“So congratulations, Olivia and mom, because I know it takes parents to get kids to do these things.”
Olivia’s mother is Councilwoman Kim Ullner, who proudly introduced her daughter to council and explained the steps Olivia took to earn the Gold Award -- the highest achievement within the Girl Scouts of the USA.
Only 5.4 percent of eligible Girl Scouts earn the award, according to the Girl Scouts of the USA website.
The proclamation states that girls who pursue the Gold Award aspire to transform an idea and vision for change into an actionable plan with “measurable, sustainable and far-reaching results.”
Olivia, who was born in Guatemala but raised in Orange, wanted to create a project that would help her birth country and also connect with her adopted one, Kim Ullner said.
“Olivia found a local nonprofit, H(e)arts 4 Guatemala, based in Chagrin Falls, and through its director was able to identify a medical clinic in Izabal, Guatemala,” Ullner said.
Olivia’s project consisted of setting up a new program collecting and delivering eyeglasses and hearing aids to this medical clinic, as well as earning funds to purchase medical equipment for the clinic.
The project is titled “Eyes and Ears for Guatemala.”
“The medical clinic planned to expand to include eye care and had an identified need for eyeglasses, hearing aids and a piece of medical equipment,” Ullner said.
“Olivia far exceeded her original goal of collecting 200 pairs of eyeglasses and hearing aids and collected 800 pairs of glasses and hearing aids, which were delivered.
“This project keeps glasses and hearing aids out of our landfills, and they are cleaned and given new life to help children and adults in Guatemala who really need them.”
Olivia, 17, recognizes that the best way out of poverty is education, Ullner said.
She noted that only 55 percent of Guatemalan children attend primary school, and even fewer complete primary school and go on to high school -- only seven out of every 100 children.
“For children with vision and/or hearing impairments, those numbers are even lower,” Ullner said.
“This project aims to help make glasses and hearing aids available to those most vulnerable and most in need.
“Indeed, if children and adults in Guatemala can have their medical and educational needs met, they can become productive members of society and support themselves.”
To earn some money for her project, Olivia assembled a team and collected nearly 12,000 pounds of clothes and shoes, for which she was paid by the pound, Ullner said.
She also sold Girl Scout cookies and received a grant from the Kiwanis Club of Lander Circle, based in Pepper Pike.
“All told, she earned $3,000, which she used to purchase a key piece of medical equipment -- an ophthalmoscope with 20 diopter lenses and long-range battery -- so the doctor can go into the field to treat and diagnose residents who cannot get to the clinic,” Ullner said.
“With this piece of medical equipment, the clinic’s director hopes to diagnose and treat eye disease early to prevent patients from losing their vision.”
The money Olivia earned was also used to pay to ship collected glasses and hearing aids to Izabal, Ullner said.
Olivia’s project is being continued by the student board of H(e)arts 4 Guatemala, Ullner said.
The board has begun to bring the project to area schools, such as Hathaway Brown and Kenston, as well as Chagrin Falls after the holidays, she said.
Collection boxes for glasses and hearing aids are located at those schools, as well as at Orange High School, Moreland Hills Elementary School and Orange Village Hall.
Olivia has been a Girl Scout since second grade.
According to Ullner, she will be the first girl to graduate from Orange High School as a “Trifecta Girl Scout,” which means she has earned the Girl Scout Bronze, Silver and Gold awards.
For the Bronze Award, Olivia and several fellow troop members earned money to purchase a bullet- and stab-proof vest for the Orange Police Department’s K-9 officer, Deacon, who has since retired.
For the Silver Award, she worked with two other Girl Scouts to increase kindness in the community and created a “kindness rock garden,” Ullner said.
“Olivia will be the only Orange High School senior to graduate this year having earned the Gold Award,” her mother said.
Olivia plans to continue her study of American Sign Language in college, as she hopes to earn a degree in ASL English interpreting and become a community interpreter and teacher of the deaf, Ullner said.
“Olivia exemplifies kindness, caring and dedication to community service,” she said.
“She intends to continue her commitment of giving back to her community and making the world a better place.
“I could not be prouder of Olivia. I know that she will continue to do great things.”
Olivia said she was surprised but pleased to receive the proclamation.
She said she learned she would be receiving it about 15 minutes before the council meeting began.

author: Katalin Nagy
title: 5 Unhealthy Eating Habits You Didn't Know Were Sabotaging Your Health - NewsBreak
text: You may think you are eating healthy and getting all the essential nutrients you need. But there is a good chance you are still guilty of these unhealthy eating habits that may derail your efforts to eat well. With a little help from UC Davis, we are going to take a look at these bad eating habits that might be quietly wrecking your health. It’s never too late to make a change! Note: The content of this article is for informational purposes only and is not a substitute for professional advice. Always consult with a qualified professional for advice tailored to your individual circumstances. Late-night snacking feels so right at the moment, but your body might disagree once you finally hit the pillow. Eating too close to bedtime can seriously mess with your metabolism. It may even spike your blood pressure and even increase your risk of heart disease over time. Not to mention, it’s a sneaky way to pack on extra pounds without even realizing it. Your metabolism slows down at night, which means your body isn’t burning as many calories while you sleep, so those late-night nachos are more likely to be stored as fat rather than used by your body for energy. Eating late at night can also sometimes trigger acid reflux. If you go to bed with a full stomach, you might wake up feeling bloated or even have heartburn, which is not exactly a great way to start the day. Not to mention that your blood sugar and blood pressure can rise from those late-night meals, and over time, this can increase your risk of heart disease. Try setting a “kitchen curfew” where you stop eating 2-3 hours before bed to give your body time to digest. If you really need a late-night snack, keep it light. A small handful of nuts or a piece of fruit won’t weigh you down like a burger and fries. You might think skipping meals saves calories, but doing this can actually backfire big time. When you go too long without eating, your blood sugar drops, making you feel tired, cranky, and foggy-brained. By the time you finally eat, you’re so hungry that you’re way more likely to overeat or make unhealthy choices. When you skip a meal, your metabolism slows down, and your body may go into “starvation mode,” where it holds onto fat instead of burning it. Your energy levels may also crash as no food fuel = no energy. The best thing to do is simply eat something, even if it’s small. A simple banana, a small handful of nuts, or even a Greek yogurt is better than nothing! Try to plan your meals and snacks ahead of time, which can be a lifesaver when life gets busy. Instead of skipping a meal, you’ll be prepared with healthy foods that you enjoy! If your meal disappears in five minutes flat, your body barely has time to realize it’s eating. Your brain needs about 20 minutes to recognize that you’re full, so if you eat too fast, you might end up consuming way more than you actually need. When you eat quickly, you’re more likely to have indigestion and bloating. Swallowing food too quickly can lead to stomach pain, gas, and some serious discomfort. It can even contribute to weight gain, which, as a healthy eater, may not be on your want list. Instead of shoveling tons of food into your mouth as fast as possible, put your fork down between bites, which will force you to slow down. Always chew your food thoroughly and try to aim for at least 15-20 chews per bite (yes, really!). Have a conversation while you eat, which will also help you slow down and enjoy your food even more. Food is better with a company! Have you ever reached for a bag of chips or gone straight for that pint of ice cream after a rough day? You’re not alone. Stress eating is a real thing, and while it might make you feel better in the moment, it doesn’t actually fix anything and can even make you feel worse afterward. Stress triggers cravings for sugary, fatty foods, and those foods temporarily boost your mood. But once the sugar crash hits? You’re back to feeling both stressed and now also guilty. Stress eating also increases your calorie intake without real hunger. Your body isn’t actually hungry, but you are just looking for comfort. So eating when you are stressed doesn’t address the real issue but only distracts you from what’s actually bothering you. So, before you eat, pause and ask yourself: Am I actually hungry or just stressed? Consider going for a walk or listening to music instead of reaching for junk food. But, also try to keep healthy snacks on hand because, if you must munch, eating something healthy and good for you is the best option! Boredom eating is always a tricky one. You’re not eating because you’re hungry; you’re eating because there’s literally nothing else to do. You open the fridge, stare at its contents, and grab something just because it’s there. But, when you eat mindlessly, you’re not even enjoying your food. You’re just filling time. That means you consume extra, unnecessary calories, which, over time, can really add up. Boredom eating also becomes a habit. The more you do it, the more automatic it becomes. Instead of always reaching for the snacks when you are bored, find a distraction instead. Call a friend, go for a walk, or do something creative instead of reaching for food. You should also always start by drinking a glass of water as sometimes, thirst is mistaken for hunger. Bad eating habits can be tricky to catch, but once you are aware of these little eating mistakes, you can start making better choices. Start following these tips today, and your body will thank you later! This article was inspired by UC Davis and was first published at Spatula Desserts . The post 5 Unhealthy Eating Habits You Didn’t Know Were Sabotaging Your Health appeared first on Spatula Desserts .

author: @zazoomblog
title: Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth è disponibile ora anche su PC ecco il trailer di lancio
text:
Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth è disponibile ora anche su PC ecco il trailer di lancio Game-experience.it | 23 gen 2025 L’attesa è finita: Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth , il secondo capitolo del progetto di rifacimento del leggendario JRPG, sbarca Final mente su PC. Square Enix ha celebrato il lancio con un trailer che introduce le novità di questo capitolo, proseguendo l’epica avventura di Cloud e compagni in un mondo vasto e ricco di pericoli.Già acclamato dalla critica, il gioco si arricchisce ora di miglioramenti tecnici che sfruttano al massimo il potenziale dei PC di fascia alta, come abbiamo visto nella nostra recensione. Precisiamo comunque che in Rebirth , l’azione si sposta oltre la metropoli distopica di Midgar, aprendo le porte a un mondo open world vivo e pieno di cose da fare.I giocatori possono esplorare paesaggi sconfinati, cavalcare chocobo attraverso pianure rigogliose e affrontare missioni ed eventi in un universo ricco di dettagli.
